results.title: Orchestras Are Rushing to Add Black Composers. Will It Last?

results.title: Six Months in the Life of a Locked-Down Theater
results.abstract: Britain’s National Theater hopes to reopen in October after being closed for more than 200 days. But even with the shutters down, it’s been an eventful and emotional time for its staff.

results.title: What the ‘Cuties’ Critics Can’t See: The Complexities of Black Girlhood
results.abstract: The Netflix film and a handful of other recent titles movingly explore what it means to come of age at the crossroads of racism and sexism.

multimedia.caption: Fathia Youssouf in “Cuties.” Her character struggles to define herself in both a traditional household and a social media-driven society.

results.title: My Screens Are Filled With Black Death, but I Won’t Look Away
results.abstract: Scenes of racist brutality both real, in news videos, and imagined, in series like “The Boys,” can veer between exposure and exploitation. But sometimes we need to pay the price of our contentment.

results.title: Terry Goodkind, Master of Fantasy Fiction, Is Dead at 72
results.abstract: His epic series “The Sword of Truth” spanned 17 books and sold more than 25 million copies worldwide. But his views angered some readers.

multimedia.caption: The author Terry Goodkind at his home in Nevada in 2016. His fantasy novels were popular, one critic wrote, “in part because, in a complicated world, he boils things down to stark contrasts.”

results.title: Remembering a Father’s Love of the Dystopian
results.abstract: In the middle of a plague, a son thinks back to the way his father devoured any book that intimated disaster was near.

results.title: Jacques-Louis Monod, Modernist Composer With a Lyrical Touch, Dies at 93
results.abstract: Mr. Monod was an uncompromising champion of composers of the Second Viennese School, including Arnold Schoenberg and Anton Webern.

multimedia.caption: The conductor, composer and pianist Jacques-Louis Monod, who studied at the Paris Conservatoire, came to New York in the 1950s and established Camera Concerts, one of the first concert series devoted to modern music. He is shown at the piano in 1955 with, from left, Isidore Cohen, violinist; Charles McCracken, violist; Eugene Kushner, flutist; and Mark Fischer, French horn player.

results.title: Murray Schisgal, Who Brought the Absurd to the Mainstream, Dies at 93
results.abstract: With “Luv” on Broadway and “Tootsie” on the screen, he wrote with knowing, slightly askew humor about subjects like sex, family and failure.

results.title: Sometimes, the Funny Thing About Poetry Is the Poems
results.abstract: Two debut collections, Sumita Chakraborty’s “Arrow” and Chessy Normile’s “Great Exodus, Great Wall, Great Party,” both show that humor can be a valuable weapon in a serious poet’s arsenal.
des_facet: Great Exodus, Great Wall, Great Party (Book)

multimedia.caption: Humor can be used as a defense mechanism, but it’s also a reclamation of control — a refusal to be told how to feel about your own lived (and relived) experience.

results.title: ‘Chad and Not Chadwick’: How the Bosemans Remember a Superstar
